newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: SAB SAYS MADE "NO FORMAL BID" FOR BBAG.
newsitem.headline: SAB SAYS MADE "NO FORMAL BID" FOR BBAG.

text.p: South African Breweries Ltd (SAB), the world's fourth biggest brewer, said on Tuesday that it had made no formal bid for Austrian drinks firm BBAG.
Earlier BBAG said its majority shareholders had rejected a takeover bid by drinks giant SAB.
"The controlling shareholders, who met today on short notice because of rumours in several media, have unanimously rejected the takeover designs by South African Breweries," BBAG said in a statement.
But SAB corporate finance and development director Malcolm Wyman told Reuters that his firm had never made any formal approach for BBAG.
"There was no formal bid, no formal negotiations," he said.

Wyman said SAB had informally approached one of the controlling shareholders of BBAG about talks on a range of issues, one of which was the possibility of buying shares in BBAG's ultimate holding firm.
Wyman, who declined to name the shareholder, said SAB had found that the shares were not for sale. "We have not made any takeover bid," he said.
BBAG, one of Europe's top ten brewers with wide interests in Eastern Europe, has a complicated holding structure that is effectively controlled by five families.
The families control a non-operative holding company, called Getraenke Holding (Drinks Holding), which through a series of further holding firms owns the majority stake in operative unit Brau Union.
SAB has recently expanded rapidly in Central and Eastern Europe, snapping up businesses in Poland, Hungary and Romania.
